It depends. Some champions are a bit unfair in how they're almost unkillable by the squishy but can actually threaten bursting/pseudo-bursting the squishy. Typically champions who can build full Tank and still maintain this threat. (i.e Poppy). Then there's champions who are almost unkillable, but do not maintain this threat like Shen. Shen feels infinitely more fair than Poppy because I may not be able to easily kill him, but he can't easily kill me.

Then you go into bruiser territory where they build 1-2 damage items. This makes them realistically killable, but threaten kill pressure. This feels fair because with good play, either side can kill each other.

Alternatively there's this line of thinking; "Why am I spending Gold on damage and taking a risk by being squishy, when their Tank is spending Gold on defense and still killing me just as easily?" This line of thinking is what created Tank Ekko and Tank Fizz. Why take the risk of being a squishy melee Assassin, when I can build Tank and still do my job while infinitely reducing the risk?

shen is also kneecapped to hell.

In a fight between most squishy and tanks, tanks should win, not one combo win, but still win.

Think of it like a village vs a glacier. the village can pop up and exist for a while, and its all good, and the village can build things to hold the thng down and can try to cut the glacier back, but try as they might the glacier will still roll over them in time.

Regardless of numbers, Shen's damage is backloaded into 3 Q autos, compared to Poppy whose burst is pretty frontloaded.

Tanks should win through attrition, not doing 50% of a squishy's health at a minimum.

Honestly, squishy natural defenses should be upped ever so slightly. There's not much of a point going glass cannon when I can still burst squishies on 300-400 AP late game. Why buy that deathcap when I can get a GA or HP/AP item or whatever.

Generally speaking, Tanks need a base level of damage to function in lane. Otherwise, they would get out pushed, out farmed, and bullied out of lane. Similar problem with Jungle, they need to keep up with their counterparts, or they will get out leveled. So the only Tank who doesn't actually care about damage is the support tank. (And as a support main, I really don't want to be obligated to playing the teams tank.) 

I think the real trick though, is to shape Tank's damage into AoE, so that they are not doing a ton of damage to a single Target. (But it could mean that they deal a lot of Total damage in the end game stats) You could also use a Damage amp against minions, to insure that Tank damage isn't oppressive against champions. 

But regardless, Glass cannons are Glass cannons. If you don't build any defenses, and your opponent doesn't build any offenses. The enemy tank's damage is going to be comparable at all stages of the game. (Notable changes though, would be increased damage in abilities as they level)

Being squishy simply means that it takes relatively less nominal damage to kill you. It has nothing to do with who can/can't kill you. Also, damage is damage, regardless of whether it is applied to a tank or a squishy.

With that said, some "tanks" {{champion:36}}  do more damage than others because of how difficult it is for them to actually apply their damage. All of that has to be considered.
Mundo isn't really a tank though. He's closer to your Illaois and Garens than your Malphites and Nautiluses. In other words; he's a Juggernaut.

Similarly, just because you built tanky does not mean you should survive 10 seconds of a full offensive build marksman wailing on you. Against a tanky opponent, though, you should expect to survive [literally forever](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pr-y1VLftB0). Balance in all things, folks.

I dunno about anyone else, but I consider "squishy" to be less than 2.5k effective health (the amount of total damage required to kill you, without accounting for sustain effects like healing or regeneration) when late-game rolls around.

Basically, if it takes less than 2.5k damage from anyone to kill you, you're squishy. You're vulnerable enough to be killed by:

-A few stray skillshots
-Most of an Assassin or Mage burst combo
-The sweeping damage of a teamfight (meaning you have to be careful where you stand to attack)
-Anything else of this sort

Basically, if you're someone who can be killed easily enough to be focussed, or if getting stunned is a death sentence because you're no longer able to protect yourself, whether you're being focussed or not.

Most champions are not squishy when lv16-18 comes up. By that same note, if you aren't "squishy" by this definition (as a matter of opinion, I'm hardly LCS material), you shouldn't be whining about your team not protecting you. You should be playing more carefully.

Squishy vs High damage: Near instant death

Squishy vs Moderate damage: Death after a 4-7 second struggle if you aren't protected or full build.

Squishy vs Low damage: Unless you are behind or on critical HP, you are probably not going to die from this.  They, however, can make you easy prey for the others.

Squishies should always be on their toes, but they should have priorities. It's a problem if your ADC gets ulted by Camille in a baron fight. It's GG if they get ulted by Syndra.

Champs with low base hp and low base resistances (armor+mr). They also typically do not build much in terms of armor or mr.

Tanks and bruisers have high base damage both to farm effectively and to give them some meaningful way of dealing damage in fights. Thus even if they build zero or one offensive item, they are still a threat to adc's, mids, supports, and some carry junglers early on in 1v1 scenarios.
They pay for this by lacking range - so that enemy ranged squishies (mages, supports in some cases, and adc's) must use their range advantage to overcome the base stat advantage of many melees.
For the longest time, this was around 4-5 items for most adc's. Thus adc's were late-game carries while bruisers, tanks, and mages (who could delete someone quickly in mid-game fights) had more influence early/mid game.

All that said, a tank or bruiser can be squishy. If one team gets too far ahead, the tank/bruiser cannot get enough resistances fast enough. Just look to the NA LCS finals and watch "tank" nautilus get melted. Or... a tank or bruiser could itemize for damage instead of tankiness - like building 4 damage items on {{champion:122}} {{champion:86}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:114}} . Because they have 4 damage items, their innate base tankiness compared to some other champs is not nearly enough to survive focused fire by 3-4 enemies in a late game teamfight. Almost certainly their one tank item will be {{item:3026}} . This gives them a CHANCE to delete an enemy carry (due to their excessive amount of damage items) and then revive after the enemy team nukes them down. But they would be a "squishy" champ in my books with 4 damage items and only 1 resistance or resistance+hp item to their name.
